Question_1.Context: The study aimed to explore the efficacy of targeted alpha therapy (TAT) in treating neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) using a specific radiolabeled peptide.
Question_1.Question: What was the stability of [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 in phosphate buffered saline (PBS) and mouse serum?
Question_1.A: 77% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in PBS and ~81% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in mouse serum
Question_1.B: 56.6% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in PBS and 81.0% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in mouse serum
Question_1.C: 95% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in PBS and 94% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in mouse serum
Question_1.D: 81% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in PBS and 81% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in mouse serum
Question_1.Source: Stability studies were performed, showing [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 had 77% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in PBS and ~81% intact radiopeptide at 24 h in mouse serum.

Question_2.Context: The study investigated the binding affinity of DOTA-JR11 to somatostatin receptor 2 (SSTR2) after complexation with different nuclides.
Question_2.Question: How did the binding affinity of natLa-DOTA-JR11 and natLu-DOTA-JR11 compare to DOTA-JR11 in competitive binding assays?
Question_2.A: natLa-DOTA-JR11 and natLu-DOTA-JR11 exhibited similar binding affinity to SSTR2 compared to DOTA-JR11
Question_2.B: natLa-DOTA-JR11 showed higher binding affinity than DOTA-JR11, while natLu-DOTA-JR11 showed lower binding affinity
Question_2.C: natLa-DOTA-JR11 and natLu-DOTA-JR11 showed lower binding affinity than DOTA-JR11
Question_2.D: natLa-DOTA-JR11 and natLu-DOTA-JR11 showed no binding affinity to SSTR2
Question_2.Source: Competitive binding assay revealed that natLa-DOTA-JR11 and natLu-DOTA-JR11 exhibited similar binding affinity for SSTR2 compared to the parent peptide DOTA-JR11.

Question_3.Context: The study focused on the biodistribution profile of [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 in comparison to [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11 in vivo.
Question_3.Question: What was the tumor uptake of [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 at 4 hours post-injection?
Question_3.Source: High tumor uptake of 7.7 ± 0.9% IA/g was observed at 4 hours post-injection of [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11.

Question_4.Context: The study aimed to compare the dosimetry of [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 and [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11 in targeted alpha therapy (TAT) for NETs.
Question_4.Question: What was the absorbed dose to the liver for [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 compared to [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11?
Question_4.Source: The absorbed dose to the liver was 271.4 mGy for [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 and 38.5 mGy for [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11.

Question_5.Context: The study evaluated the potential radiotoxicity of [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 in non-targeted organs for targeted alpha therapy (TAT) of NETs.
Question_5.Question: What was the absorbed dose to the kidneys for [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 compared to [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11?
Question_5.Source: The absorbed dose to the kidneys was 952.6 mGy for [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 and 406.9 mGy for [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11.

Question_6.Context: The study aimed to investigate the potential of [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 for targeted alpha therapy (TAT) of NETs.
Question_6.Question: What was the tumor-to-kidney ratio for [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11?

Question_7.Context: The study focused on the biodistribution profile of [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 in comparison to [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11 in vivo.
Question_7.Question: What was the kidney uptake of [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 at 4 hours post-injection?
Question_7.Source: High kidney uptake of 19.3 ± 2.6% IA/g was observed at 4 hours post-injection of [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11.

Question_8.Context: The study aimed to compare the dosimetry of [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 and [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11 in targeted alpha therapy (TAT) for NETs.
Question_8.Question: What was the absorbed dose to the tumor for [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 compared to [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11?
Question_8.Source: The absorbed dose to the tumor was 328.5 mGy for [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 and 464.4 mGy for [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11.

Question_9.Context: The study evaluated the potential radiotoxicity of [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 in non-targeted organs for targeted alpha therapy (TAT) of NETs.
Question_9.Question: What was the absorbed dose to the spleen for [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 compared to [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11?
Question_9.Source: The absorbed dose to the spleen was 76.4 mGy for [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 and 8.4 mGy for [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11.

Question_10.Context: The study aimed to investigate the potential of [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 for targeted alpha therapy (TAT) of NETs.
Question_10.Question: What was the absorbed dose to the intestines for [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 compared to [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11?
Question_10.Source: The absorbed dose to the intestines was 40.3 mGy for [225Ac]Ac-DOTA-JR11 and 23.4 mGy for [177Lu]Lu-DOTA-JR11.
